description: The Nebraska Attorney Generals Office filed charges in Dawes County Court on May 20 against a Panhandle sheriff, who allegedly refused to receive and keep a lawfully committed offender in his prison. Dawes County Sheriff Karl Dailey has been charged with misconduct after he knowingly violated a statute or lawfully adopted rule or regulation relating to his...
text:
The Nebraska Attorney Generals Office filed charges in Dawes County Court on
May 20 against a Panhandle sheriff, who allegedly refused to receive and keep
a lawfully committed offender in his prison.

Dawes County Sheriff Karl Dailey has been charged with misconduct after he
knowingly violated a statute or lawfully adopted rule or regulation relating
to his official duties as Sheriff or Jailer for Dawes County, on our about
July 21, 2019, according to the complaint.

The complaint accuses Dailey of refusing to accept Jesse Sierra into the Dawes
County jail. The charging document cites Nebraska State Statute 23-1703 which
sets out the duty of a sheriff supervising a county prison and says that a
sheriff is required to receive those lawfully committed and to keep them ...
until discharged by law.

Dailey's lawyer, Charles Brewster his client intends to plead not guilty when
he appears on the charge this week carry it forward to trial if need be.

Jesse Sierra and his brother Dustin Sierra were indicted by federal
authorities on July 30, 2019, for kidnapping.

According to information released by the U.S. Attorneys Office for the
District of South Dakota, Sierra, the two brothers were charged after they
allegedly kidnapped a woman from Rapid City, South Dakota, on July 13, 2019,
transporting her against her will and holding her on the Pine Ridge
Reservation for several days, and eventually taking her across state lines to
Nebraska. The victim was dropped off at the hospital in Chadron, Nebraska,
severe wounds, including broken bones and bruising to her face and body, on
July 21, last year.

The Sierra brothers are currently due for trial in July 2020, according to
federal court documents.

title: Sheriff charged for refusing to receive, keep alleged woman kidnapper in Dawes County jail [Legal Monitor Worldwide]
html:
The Nebraska Attorney Generals Office filed charges in Dawes County Court on May 20 against a Panhandle sheriff, who allegedly refused to receive and keep a lawfully committed offender in his prison.

Dawes County Sheriff Karl Dailey has been charged with misconduct after he knowingly violated a statute or lawfully adopted rule or regulation relating to his official duties as Sheriff or Jailer for Dawes County, on our about July 21, 2019, according to the complaint.

The complaint accuses Dailey of refusing to accept Jesse Sierra into the Dawes County jail. The charging document cites Nebraska State Statute 23-1703 which sets out the duty of a sheriff supervising a county prison and says that a sheriff is required to receive those lawfully committed and to keep them ... until discharged by law.

Dailey's lawyer, Charles Brewster his client intends to plead not guilty when he appears on the charge this week carry it forward to trial if need be.

Jesse Sierra and his brother Dustin Sierra were indicted by federal authorities on July 30, 2019, for kidnapping.

According to information released by the U.S. Attorneys Office for the District of South Dakota, Sierra, the two brothers were charged after they allegedly kidnapped a woman from Rapid City, South Dakota, on July 13, 2019, transporting her against her will and holding her on the Pine Ridge Reservation for several days, and eventually taking her across state lines to Nebraska. The victim was dropped off at the hospital in Chadron, Nebraska, severe wounds, including broken bones and bruising to her face and body, on July 21, last year.

The Sierra brothers are currently due for trial in July 2020, according to federal court documents.
